description.narrative:
The Gender transformative and Responsible Agribusiness Investment in South East Asia (GRAISEA) programme is a joint OGB/ONL regional programme in South East Asia financed by Embassy of Sweden Bangkok office for the period January 1, 2015 - March 31, 2018(3 years and 3 months inception period). It is a regional programme based on the recognition that financial viability and gender equitable/sustainable supply chains are not mutually exclusive, and that win-win-win propositions (community/environment wins, women and men small-scale producers win, and larger businesses win) are possible.
Building on Oxfams pilots in selected commodities (palm oil and aquaculture), this programme will utilise a multi-stakeholder approach, with Oxfam acting as a convenorto bring together the diverse stakeholders to achieve the following results:
Result 1. (Contribute to) ASEAN and its member states policies have a stronger role in promoting responsible practices in agribusiness, in agribusiness investment, in small-scale agriculture and social enterprises Result 2. Small-scale producers are effectively linked up in agro-commercial value chains and women are recognized in these as central economic actors Result 3. Leading corporate agribusinesses in South East Asiahave adopted corporate social responsibility policiesand plans that support responsible practices in the value chains for women and men small-scale producers Result 4. Financial Institutions and investors in agriculture invest responsibly by introducing /developing innovative financing solutions to assist overcoming specific investment requirements (investment risks) in smallholders and buyers of these smallholders.so
This programme has been designed to take full advantage of both Oxfams and partners experiences in the region, including working with ASEAN (primarily the ASEAN Ministerial meeting on Agriculture and Forestry and SME working group) to influence the regional operating environment, as well as Oxfam?s expertise in gender equality to strengthen the individual and collective capacities of women and men smallholders. The programme works with 5 regional partners (Change Fusion, CSR Asia, Institute of Social Entrepeneurship in Asia (ISEA), SEAFish for justice network, Shujog/Impact InvestmentExchange (IIX) as well as the Oxfam GROW regional campaign team, Oxfam experts in MultiStakeholder Initiatives especially Round Table on Sustainable Palm Oil (RSPO) and Aquaculture Stewardship Council (ASC) and Oxfam offices and country partners in Indonesia,Vietnam, Cambodia, Myanmar, Philippines, and Thailand.
OGB regional office in Bangkok is lead. ONLwill be responsible for implementation as executing affiliate in Vietnam and Cambodia and provide technical (Private sector and gender) as well as overall support.
PARTNER ORGANISATION
OGB Regional Centre in Bangkok will be leading this programme and be responsible for its implementation. An interaffiliate agreement has been established between OGB and ONL re. roles and responsibilities of each. ONLwill be member of the Programme Steering Committee.
Contribution to ONL impact indicators
1 : 50% 11: 50%
GRAISEA RICEPROGRAMME In January 2017 another value chain (rice) was added to the ongoing GRAISEA programme. This programme aligns with GRAISEAs existing theory of change, programme structure and time frame (though it runs 3 months longer). The rice programme intends to haveimproved livelihoods for women and men small-scale rice producers through more responsible and inclusive valuechains, and private sector investments, and where women demonstrate economic leadership.
The programme works with stakeholders (farmer cooperatives, civil society, national governments and regional policy actors) and Private Sector (PS) (rice processingand buying companies) to develop gender transformative, equitable and responsible small-scale producer-led rice models in three key countries (Pakistan, Vietnam and Cambodia). Learning and recommendations in countries will be combined with analyses of regional and global sustainability initiatives and challenges in the rice sector, and used to influence policiesand practices of the involved PS partners, other companies in the rice sector via the Sustainable Rice Platform (SRP) amongst others, and inpromoting responsible rice with the respective governments and regional bodies like ASEAN.
The management will be done by GRAISEA PMU. Oxfam Novib will be responsible for the implementation in Cambodia and Vietnam and for advisory support from the Land, Waterand Pro-Poor Value Chains team in the Hague. This is for a total of 0,3 full time equivalent (FTE) for the full period of 18 months.
The Cambodia Oxfam country office is working on the implementation of the responsible rice value chain programme in Cambodia.
It works with local stakeholders and two rice processing and trading companies: AmruRice and SanoRice to promote organic rice production in Preah Vihear province. The project intends to increasesocial, environmental and economic sound production of organic rice, processed by AMRU and purchased by SanoRice; a premium price will be paid to farmers.
Planned results at country level: - An additional 800 farmers organized in 4 Agricultural Cooperatives (ACs) which are not yet participating ina certified organic value chain are certified during the 2017 cropping season (assuming an average of 200 farmers participating per AC) - Increased capacity of the PMUAC board and staff members on its essential union functions -PMUAC has tested organizational and financial feasibility of additional services to be provided to its members (on demand and against payments) - PMUAC board and members have accepted new business plan and structure which takes a not-for-profit union model as itsbasis - Increased capacities of women leaders in Preah Vihear ACs. - Cambodian private sector and Government of Cambodia learn frombest practices of this project.
The Cambodia Oxfam country office will be responsible for the programme implementation in Vietnam.It will work together with local NGO Development Partnership in Action (DPA).

participating-org.narrative: Oxfam Novib is one of the 17 national affiliates of the Oxfam International Confederation. It started life in 1956 as the Netherlands Organisation for International Assistance (Novib), and joined forces with Oxfam in 1994. Working together in confederation, the Oxfam affiliates can speak with one clear and compelling voice on issues of global concern: climate change, health and education forall, agriculture, trade, and conflicts and emergencies. Oxfam established this country office to support local organizations and projects. Through this local office Oxfam Novib directly contributes towards this project#s implementation.

mailing-address.narrative: PO box 30919, 2500 GX The Hague, The Netherlands

sector.narrative: The right to a sustainable livelihood
